Early Rome was ferociously exclusive. Citizenship was restricted to freeborn Romans. The *ius civitatis* â€” the right of citizenship â€” was the most jealously guarded privilege in the ancient world. It conferred legal protections, voting rights, access to public land, and exemption from certain taxes and punishments. It could not be bought. It could only be inherited or, in rare cases, granted by the Senate for extraordinary service.

Rome's Italian allies fought a war â€” the Social War of 91â€“88 BC â€” specifically to obtain Roman citizenship. The fact that they had to fight a war to get it tells you everything about how Rome valued it.
